item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation ðŸ”—

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon is often linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The article notes that similar mutilations have been observed in other livestock and wild animals, with specific body parts often removed. Two independent federal investigations in the United States have been conducted on the topic.

Early History ðŸ”—

The earliest documented outbreak of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Later, Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 1967 case of a horse named “Snippy” found mutilated in Alamosa, Colorado. The Pueblo Chieftain published the initial story. The horse’s head and neck were skinned and defleshed, and the body displayed precise cuts. No blood was present, and a medicinal odor was reported. This case was the first to link extraterrestrials and UFOs to mutilations. Wadsworth Ayer investigated the case for the Condon Committee and concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike as the cause. Two students later confessed to shooting the horse.

Cattle Mutilations 1973â€“1980 ðŸ”—

This section covers a wave of cattle mutilations reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico during the 1970s.

1973 Kansas Wave ðŸ”—

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. A series of butchered cows were found on farms in Cloud County, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” butcher. By December, law enforcement reported a wave of cattle deaths in seven counties across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, but Modlin disagreed.

1974 Nebraska Wave ðŸ”—

Reports resumed in April 1974, with a Nebraska cow found mutilated and drained of blood. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. In May, mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, with coyotes suggested as the cause. By June, mutilations were reported in Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. An unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By August 28, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when he spotted a helicopter. Authorities cautioned the public not to shoot at aircraft. Over 50 law enforcement officials attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, to discuss the mutilations. Three cases of alleged mutilations were reported in South Dakota. Newsweek became the first national outlet to cover the story. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande reported mutilations in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Mutilations were also reported in Minnesota.

1975 Colorado ðŸ”—

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI for help, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report indicated an estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing approximately $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting ðŸ”—

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. Gabe Valdez reported finding two drugs in the remains of a mutilated bull, one to tranquilize the animal and another to remove blood. On June 14, 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents ðŸ”—

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002. In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated male human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil, in 1988.

Characteristics ðŸ”—

Cattle deaths due to natural causes are extremely common. Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by the absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts are described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals are reported to have been drained of blood. Nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found.

Laboratory Reports ðŸ”—

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In one case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI, an 11-month-old bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, was found mutilated in 1978. The animal’s heart, bone, and muscle samples were sent to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, while liver samples were sent to private laboratories. The liver was found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain high levels of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were reported to be light pink and did not clot.

Helicopter Sightings ðŸ”—

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters reportedly opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported residents seeing unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter.

Official Investigations ðŸ”—

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms ðŸ”—

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger to investigate possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation ðŸ”—

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University, but no conclusive results emerged. The US Bureau of Land Management grounded all helicopters in Eastern Colorado. By December, the CBI had investigated 203 reports of cattle mutilations.

New Mexico State Police ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation headed by Officer Gabe Valdez. Valdez solicited the assistance of retired Sandia National Laboratories scientist Howard Burgess. On the night of July 5, suspecting that cattle might be “marked,” Burgess and Valdez screened the Gomez herd and found five animals marked with a chemical that fluoresced under ultraviolet light. On June 14, 1981, intact radar chaff was found near a mutilated cow on the Gomez ranch. This investigation reported finding evidence that some mutilated animals had been tranquilized and treated with an anti-coagulant.

Rommel Investigation ðŸ”—

Beginning in May 1979, an investigation was funded by a grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration and headed by retired FBI agent Kenneth Rommel. The report concluded that the mutilations were predominantly the result of natural predation, but some cases contained anomalies.

Conventional Explanations ðŸ”—

Potential explanations for cattle mutilations range from death by natural causes to purposeful acts by unknown individuals.

On April 20, 1979, C Hibbs of the New Mexico State Veterinary diagnostics Laboratory testified that mutilation fell into three categories: natural causes, deaths caused by pranksters or deviants, and animals mutilated with “sharp instruments”.

Natural Causes ðŸ”—

Missing or mutilated mouth, lips, anus, and genitalia are explained as contraction of missing/damaged areas

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry delves into the world of UFO conspiracy theories, exploring the belief that governments, particularly the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life and technology. It examines the historical development of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: the alleged suppression of evidence regarding extraterrestrial-controlled UFOs or technology. It notes the evolution of these theories, from initial claims of government cover-ups to more complex narratives involving communication and cooperation with extraterrestrials, including claims of government allowance of cattle mutilation and alien abduction. It also mentions the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry’s stance that there is little to no evidence supporting these theories.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It highlights government and independent investigations that have failed to confirm extraordinary claims made by ufologists. Prosaic explanations for UFO sightings, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes, are offered. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs and their influence on new religions. Benjamin Radford’s argument about the unlikelihood of a decades-long, international cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key figures associated with UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent voices from the 1950s to the 1970s. It also notes that some early proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, suffered from psychiatric issues, and that some proponents confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists individuals in positions of authority, such as Senator Barry Goldwater, Admiral Lord Hill-Norton, Vice Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, and astronauts Gordon Cooper and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents like Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the portrayal of government cover-ups of extraterrestrial contact in popular fiction. Films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black are cited as examples. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned. The section also notes John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, Sidney Sheldon’s novel The Doomsday Conspiracy, and the series American Horror Story: Double Feature.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and religion. It identifies new religious movements, including the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate, that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology, Theosophy, and the “I AM” Activity are also discussed. The section mentions the Nation of Islam’s concept of “The Mother Plane,” the UFO religions Unarius and the Aetherius Society, L. Ron Hubbard’s teachings about Xenu in Scientology, and the RaÃ«lism movement. It concludes with the Heaven’s Gate mass suicide and the Order of the Solar Temple mass deaths.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine Amazing Stories in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his publication of Richard Shaver’s stories about a secret underground race and Palmer’s claim that world governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection details Richard Shaver’s claims of telepathic communication with a secret underground race and their mastery of space travel. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the beginning of the flying disc craze with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting in 1947. It mentions the Roswell incident and the Army’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc.” It also discusses Palmer’s investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington, and the subsequent plane crash.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the aftermath of the Maury Island incident and the continued promotion of UFO conspiracy theories by Palmer and Shaver. It mentions Shaver’s “rock books” and Palmer’s later admission that Shaver had spent time in a mental institution. It also notes Palmer’s claim of a link between flying saucers, the Shaver Mystery, the Kennedy assassination, Watergate, and Fred Crisman.

National Coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence in the 1950s.

The Flying Saucer Conspiracy ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Donald Keyhoe’s role in promoting UFO conspiracy theories in the 1950s. It mentions his article “The Flying Saucers Are Real” and his book The Flying Saucer Conspiracy, which accused the government of covering up knowledge of flying saucers. It also describes Keyhoe’s appearance on CBS’s Armstrong Circle Theatre and the cutting of his microphone during the live broadcast.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s “alien bodies” conspiracy theory, which claimed that dead extraterrestrial beings were recovered from a flying saucer crash. It mentions Scully’s book Behind the Flying Saucers and the later exposure of Scully as a victim of confidence artists.

Air Force Accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings in the 1950s. It mentions General John Samford’s press conference on the Washington D.C. UFO incident, the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education, and Al Chop’s role as the press spokesman for Project Bluebook. It also discusses Captain Edward J. Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, which involved claims of a navy ship being made invisible and teleporting. It mentions Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende” (Carl Meredith Allen). It also discusses the annotated copy of Jessup’s book and Jessup’s death by suicide.

‘Men in Black’ Legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the legend of the Men in Black, popularized by Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers. It mentions the speculation that the men in black are government agents who harass and threaten UFO witnesses.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the growing government skepticism in the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the 1966 UFO reports in Michigan and the Air Force’s explanation that they were caused by swamp gas. It notes the ridicule that followed and the call for a Congressional investigation.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This subsection details Fred Crisman’s involvement in the JFK assassination conspiracy theories. It mentions Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and Crisman’s testimony before the New Orleans grand jury.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” referring to a government cover-up of UFO information. It mentions the film 2001: A Space Odyssey and J. Allen Hynek’s claim that Bluebook was a “Cosmic Watergate.”

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the legends of alien bodies being stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. It mentions Robert Spencer Carr’s claim that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored there.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the rise of alien abduction claims in the 1970s. It mentions the Betty and Barney Hill case, the Travis Walton incident, and the work of Budd Hopkins and Whitley Strieber.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the film’s depiction of a government cover-up and the involvement of J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallee.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection details Jesse Marcel’s role in the Roswell incident and his later statements suggesting that the debris might have been extraterrestrial. It mentions the National Enquirer’s coverage of the story and the US military’s later reports disclosing the true nature of the crashed aircraft.
